title: Martino Colacicco loses home of 50 years to Western Sydney Metro network
text:
An elderly homeowner has broken down in tears after being told he'll be kicked out of the home he's lived in for 50 years as it's knocked down for a new train line.

Martino Colacicco, 88, was told on Monday his Five Dock home in Sydney's inner west would be destroyed to make way for the new Western Sydney Metro network.

The $20billion rail link, which is due to be built next year, will see more than 115 properties being acquired by the government, leaving dozens of homeowners homeless.

'They said this is not your property anymore. This is government property,' Mr Colacicco told Nine News.

Mr Colacicco's neighbours had all sold their houses but the 88-year-old wasn't prepared to move.

'That's democracy? That's communism. Not democracy.'

Westmead resident Fred Sassine will also be losing his home to the project, one he has lived in for 45 years.

'I've been here all my life. I don't like to move from here,' he said.

As part of the new network, 92 businesses and 23 homes will all be lost.

Martino Colacicco, 88, (pictured) learnt he would be losing his home he lived in for 50 years to the new Western Sydney Metro project

Mr Colacicco's neighbours had all sold their houses but the 88-year-old wasn't prepared to leave his Five Dock home (pictured)

On Monday, seven new station locations were confirmed by NSW Transport including Westmead, Parramatta, Sydney Olympic Park, North Strathfield, Burwood North, Five Dock and the Bays Precinct.

The new network will see two tunnels connecting the CBD with Westmead via Sydney Olympic Park and Parramatta.

Premier Gladys Berejiklian said the new metro would change how commuters make their way around Sydney.

'The Western Sydney Metro will fundamentally change how we get around our city for generations to come, connecting Greater Parramatta and the Sydney CBD with fast, safe and reliable metro rail,' Ms Berejiklian said in a statement.

As part of the new network, 92 businesses and 23 homes will all be lost (pictured: station locations for new network)

Transport Minister Andrew Constance said motorists could expect to have their travel time cut by 20 minutes.

'Western Sydney Metro will more than double the existing rail capacity between Greater Parramatta and the Sydney CBD and slash travel times between Parramatta and the Sydney CBD to around 20 minutes,' Mr Constance said.

Sydney's beloved speedway in Parramatta has also been planned to be demolished to make way for the new transport system.

The Western Sydney Metro is expected to be complete by 2030.
description: Martino Colacicco, 88, learnt his Five Dock home in Sydney's inner west would be destroyed to make way for the new Western Sydney Metro network.
authors: Eliza Mcphee For Daily Mail Australia
